description:
With the release of Python 2.7.4, I decided to take a look at how many dependencies we build that are out of date.  It turns out that many of the packages need updating.

I've run the full unit and answer testing suite, which this passes, both with the default options, and with all of the optional packages built.  I think the only major probable source of breakage is the version bump from numpy 1.6 to 1.7.

All of the files have already been deployed on yt-project.org.

EDIT: Reverting changes unrelated to the install script.
EDIT2: Falling back to hdf5-1.8.9.
title: Updating the dependencies in the install script

pullrequest.title: Updating the dependencies in the install script

content.raw: I believe this probably won't do the Right Thing, since none of the data formats will have been loaded at this time.  Instead of changing the mods import, it's potentially easier to do what `startup_tasks.py` expects (line 121), which is to set the `__command_line` var in `ytcfg`, as is done in `yt/utilities/command_line.py`.
content.html: I believe this probably won't do the Right Thing, since none of the data formats will have been loaded at this time. Instead of changing the mods import, it's potentially easier to do what startup_tasks.py expects (line 121), which is to set the __command_line var in ytcfg, as is done in yt/utilities/command_line.py.

pullrequest.title: Updating the dependencies in the install script

content.raw:
There are binary incompatibilities with Numpy 1.7.  It is possible that this will require recompilation of all numpy-using extensions, and I have not finished evaluating Numpy 1.7 as being completely compatible with yt.

http://numpy-discussion.10968.n7.nabble.com/ANN-NumPy-1-7-0-release-td32809.html
content.html:
There are binary incompatibilities with Numpy 1.7. It is possible that this will require recompilation of all numpy-using extensions, and I have not finished evaluating Numpy 1.7 as being completely compatible with yt.

http://numpy-discussion.10968.n7.nabble.com/ANN-NumPy-1-7-0-release-td32809.html

pullrequest.title: Updating the dependencies in the install script

content.raw:
Hi Nathan, thanks for coming up with all the updated packages and the nose issue.  In the past, we have been relatively conservative about upgrading packages.  Particularly with the new `--all` option, updating without a concrete use case can result in multiple source trees inside a single yt installation directory.  My concern is that most of these upgrades are not to gain a particular feature, or to be forward compatible, but because the existing packages have new versions.  While I very much would like to take advantage of new features, and ensure that we are not missing any security or performance issues in older versions, it's not clear to me that these have had justified use cases.

I think as long as we ensure that each package upgrade has a justified use case, we should update them; but I don't know that we've done so in this case.  It's also worthwhile to consider splitting up the pull requests, so that we have a single PR for each of the two big features -- here we have both a large upgrade to the package system, along with the bug fix, which is a Nose fix.

It will be quite nice to have nose operate properly!  :)
content.html:
Hi Nathan, thanks for coming up with all the updated packages and the nose issue. In the past, we have been relatively conservative about upgrading packages. Particularly with the new --all option, updating without a concrete use case can result in multiple source trees inside a single yt installation directory. My concern is that most of these upgrades are not to gain a particular feature, or to be forward compatible, but because the existing packages have new versions. While I very much would like to take advantage of new features, and ensure that we are not missing any security or performance issues in older versions, it's not clear to me that these have had justified use cases.

I think as long as we ensure that each package upgrade has a justified use case, we should update them; but I don't know that we've done so in this case. It's also worthwhile to consider splitting up the pull requests, so that we have a single PR for each of the two big features -- here we have both a large upgrade to the package system, along with the bug fix, which is a Nose fix.

It will be quite nice to have nose operate properly! :)

pullrequest.title: Updating the dependencies in the install script

content.raw:
I understand where you're coming from regarding some of the updates I've suggested.  As far as numpy and zeromq go, I don't think there is a big issue at this point since all of the tests pass and the notebook runs as expected.

I'd also note that I (and probably many others) have been running updated versions of these libraries, since I use a build that is not based on the install script.

I'm happy to redo this so long as I have a list of packages that we'd like to include.  Would you say that reverting all packages that didn't see a major version change would be a good place to start?
content.html:
I understand where you're coming from regarding some of the updates I've suggested. As far as numpy and zeromq go, I don't think there is a big issue at this point since all of the tests pass and the notebook runs as expected.

I'd also note that I (and probably many others) have been running updated versions of these libraries, since I use a build that is not based on the install script.

I'm happy to redo this so long as I have a list of packages that we'd like to include. Would you say that reverting all packages that didn't see a major version change would be a good place to start?

pullrequest.title: Updating the dependencies in the install script

content.raw: One last thing: if `update --all` can produce bad installations, that's the fault of the sort of braindead "just re-run the install script" algorithm it uses and not the updates themselves.
content.html: One last thing: if update --all can produce bad installations, that's the fault of the sort of braindead "just re-run the install script" algorithm it uses and not the updates themselves.

pullrequest.title: Updating the dependencies in the install script

content.raw: `update --all` does not remove old packages.  So what happens is you then end up having the source for both Python 2.7.3 and Python 2.7.4 inside `$YT_DEST/src/`.  And I guess my question is, why?  What benefits from the 2.7.4 changelog are we providing?  I am not suggesting that we need to retain old version numbers in perpetuity, but I don't think it's appropriate to blame the "braindead algorithm" when we have not been good "quota stewards."
content.html: update --all does not remove old packages. So what happens is you then end up having the source for both Python 2.7.3 and Python 2.7.4 inside $YT_DEST/src/. And I guess my question is, why? What benefits from the 2.7.4 changelog are we providing? I am not suggesting that we need to retain old version numbers in perpetuity, but I don't think it's appropriate to blame the "braindead algorithm" when we have not been good "quota stewards."

pullrequest.title: Updating the dependencies in the install script

content.raw:
I guess one benefit of upgrading dependencies is that it keeps us out in front of API breakages and the like that might only get discovered by people doing manual installs.  Also, even if we aren't using any new features, it's possible our users are or they want to, which might force them to go rogue and start customizing their installs, which will likely lead to more yt-users emails.

I'm not really sure what to do about code pileup in the src directory.  I think the way the --all option works is the best we can do without having some sort of package management system.  We don't actually update dependencies that often and the sources aren't super huge.  The python tarball and source is about 80 MB together.  Over time, this could get bad, but I think even over the average life of a computer (other than Sam's laptop), it won't be a terribly big deal.
content.html:
I guess one benefit of upgrading dependencies is that it keeps us out in front of API breakages and the like that might only get discovered by people doing manual installs. Also, even if we aren't using any new features, it's possible our users are or they want to, which might force them to go rogue and start customizing their installs, which will likely lead to more yt-users emails.

I'm not really sure what to do about code pileup in the src directory. I think the way the --all option works is the best we can do without having some sort of package management system. We don't actually update dependencies that often and the sources aren't super huge. The python tarball and source is about 80 MB together. Over time, this could get bad, but I think even over the average life of a computer (other than Sam's laptop), it won't be a terribly big deal.

pullrequest.title: Updating the dependencies in the install script

content.raw:
I guess I'm +0 on some packages and -0 on others.  Specifically I'm -0 on hdf5 since it provides so little new: http://www.hdfgroup.org/HDF5/doc/ADGuide/Changes.html

I'm also -0 on python 2.7.4 just because i could see it confusing users to see "installing python, this may take a while..." when doing an update.  I know if I hit that unexpectedly and was just casually updating, i'd be angry that now my computer was busy installing python when I didn't really need it...

Cython 0.18 seems to lead to the weird grid_traversal.pyx heisenbug that Kascper and I keep seeing.  I think we should make an effort to figure that out before pushing it.

I don't know the intricacies of numpy to comment.

The rest I'm +0 on since they are don't seem like they would be an issue.

My last comment is a request to in the future not sprinkle in pep8 fixes along with actual changes since it makes the diff somewhat of a pain to read.  I'm in favor of pep8 fixes, but maybe in more of a coordinated effort.

Thanks, Nathan, for going through and finding all the new updated packages.
content.html:
I guess I'm +0 on some packages and -0 on others. Specifically I'm -0 on hdf5 since it provides so little new: http://www.hdfgroup.org/HDF5/doc/ADGuide/Changes.html

I'm also -0 on python 2.7.4 just because i could see it confusing users to see "installing python, this may take a while..." when doing an update. I know if I hit that unexpectedly and was just casually updating, i'd be angry that now my computer was busy installing python when I didn't really need it...

Cython 0.18 seems to lead to the weird grid_traversal.pyx heisenbug that Kascper and I keep seeing. I think we should make an effort to figure that out before pushing it.

I don't know the intricacies of numpy to comment.

The rest I'm +0 on since they are don't seem like they would be an issue.

My last comment is a request to in the future not sprinkle in pep8 fixes along with actual changes since it makes the diff somewhat of a pain to read. I'm in favor of pep8 fixes, but maybe in more of a coordinated effort.

Thanks, Nathan, for going through and finding all the new updated packages.

content.raw: My hope was that this is backwards compatible - i.e. the `gcc` executable is available on 10.6 and earlier.  If not, this should probably be updated to suggest `gcc-4.2` if `gcc` fails.
content.html: My hope was that this is backwards compatible - i.e. the gcc executable is available on 10.6 and earlier. If not, this should probably be updated to suggest gcc-4.2 if gcc fails.

pullrequest.title: Updating the dependencies in the install script

content.raw:
Okay.  I have thought about this, and I think here's where I'm at: most of these dependency updates seem to be okay.  Even the Cython one we should simply address full-on.  So Nathan, do you think this is otherwise ready to go?

But, in the future, I think we should open up discussion of dep updating on the mailing list -- just in case, and because we have so many people that kind of rely on this script.
content.html:
Okay. I have thought about this, and I think here's where I'm at: most of these dependency updates seem to be okay. Even the Cython one we should simply address full-on. So Nathan, do you think this is otherwise ready to go?

But, in the future, I think we should open up discussion of dep updating on the mailing list -- just in case, and because we have so many people that kind of rely on this script.

pullrequest.title: Updating the dependencies in the install script

content.raw:
Yes, this should be fine to go in as is.

Agreed on bringing up future package upgrades on the mailing list - I would have done so in the first place if I had anticipated how controversial this turned out to be.
content.html:
